div.p: The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI
Doowon Kim1, Bum Jun Kwon1, Kristin Kozk2, Christopher Gates3, and Tudor Dumitra1 1University of Maryland, College Park, 2Masaryk University, 3Symantec
Why is the Code Signing PKI required?
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 2
Nature of software distributed over the Internet Unidentifiable software authors (publishers) May be tampered
Why is the Code Signing PKI required?
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 3
Code signing PKI helps establish Authenticity of publisher Integrity of software
Abuse and Primary Defense Abuse cases
Primary defense: Revocation Compromised certificates must be revoked To make them no longer valid
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 4
Motivation In our prior work, we found that 2/3 compromised
Why are the most not revoked yet? Furthermore, do CAs properly understand the code
signing PKI and revoke compromised certificates without any mistakes?
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 5
We measure the effectiveness of revocations
How to Revoke Potentially Compromised Certificates?
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 6
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 7
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 8
RQ1) How promptly do CAs discover and revoke compromised certificates after they appear in the wild? We found delays of 5.6 months to revoke
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 9
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 10
One-to-many relationship A certificate is used to sign numerous samples C.f., TLS, one-to-one relationship
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 11
RQ2) Do CAs properly revoke them and invalidate all malwares? We found that CAs improperly revoke 5% compromised
certificates and 5% signed malware are still valid More critical and challenging than TLS
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 12
RQ2) Do CAs properly revoke them and invalidate all malwares? We found that CAs improperly revoke 5% compromised
certificates and 5% signed malware are still valid More critical and challenging than TLS
- Always-available for clients - Must not remove expired certificates in CRLs
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 13
Trusted Timestamping Trusted creation timestamp of a program
Extend trust in the program beyond expiration date
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 14
Trusted Timestamping Trusted creation timestamp of a program
Extend trust in the program beyond expiration date
Must care about even expired certificates
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 15
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 16
RQ3) Do CAs properly maintain revocation information and disseminate it? We found that CAs removed 278 certificates from CRLs
and improperly maintain infrastructures More critical and more challenging than TLS
RQ3) Do CAs properly maintain revocation information and disseminate it? We found that CAs removed 278 certificates from CRLs
and improperly maintain infrastructures More critical and more challenging than TLS
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 17
Contributions We identified the effective revocation process
We measured the effective revocation process and showed that revocation in the code signing PKI is more critical and more challenging than TLS
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 18
Outline Data collection Results: Effectiveness of revocation process
Discovery of compromised certificates Invalidation of all signed malware Dissemination of revocation information
Data Collection: Challenges No large corpus of code singing certificates
TLS: Censys.io, IPv4 scanning, Alexa 1M domains, etc Unable to know when certificates are revoked
Revocation date: The date that determines the validity of signed sample
C.f., TLS: The date at which the revocation took place
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 20
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 21
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 22
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 23
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 24
Outline Data collection Results: Effectiveness of revocation process
Discovery of compromised certificates Invalidation of all signed malware Dissemination of revocation information
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 26
Collaborate with security companies to promptly discover compromised certificates
Promptly start investigations and revoke them Revocation delay (tp td) should be as short as possible
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 27
Collaborate with security companies to promptly discover compromised certificates
Promptly start investigations and revoke them Revocation delay should be as short as possible
Revocation delay: tp td td : the earliest detection dates of signed malware
E.g., the earliest submission date of VirusTotal tp : the dates when revoked serial numbers are added
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 28
Revocation Delay: Result Delay (tp - td) : from 1 day to 1,553 days (4.25 years)
Clients remain exposed to this threat for 5 months
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 29
Estimation of Compromised Certificates Estimate the # of abused certificates in the wild
Used the mark-recapture methodology Due to no corpus of code signing certificates to cover all
code signing certificates in the wild
Population: n1: VirusTotal hunting data set n2: Symantec telemetry data set
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 30
P: Intersection of two samples N1: sample #1 N2: sample #2
Estimated compromised certificates are 2.74X larger than actually observed
Even large security companies cannot cover most of compromised certificates in the wild A cause of long
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 31
Outline Data collection Effectiveness of revocation process
Discovery of compromised certificates Invalidation of all signed malware Dissemination of revocation information
Role in the Second Step CAs should decide the effective revocation dates (tr)
to invalidate all malware signed with the compromised certificate
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 33
What is the Effective Revocation Dates (tr)? Revocation will be made dependent on a specific
It determines the validity of signed samples Depending on tr signed samples become valid or invalid
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 34
What is the Effective Revocation Dates (tr)? Revocation will be made dependent on an effective

What is the Effective Revocation Dates (tr)? Revocation will be made dependent on an effective
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 36
What is the Effective Revocation Dates (tr)? Revocation will be made dependent on an effective
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 37
What is the Effective Revocation Dates (tr)?
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 38
What is the Effective Revocation Dates (tr)?
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 39
Security Threat What if sample signed before tr are malware?
Clients are exposed to the security threat
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 40
Two Types of Revocation Soft revocation: ti < tr < te
Invalidate only samples signed after tr But security threats exist
Hard revocation: tr = ti No security threats, but invalidate all benign samples
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 41
Trends of Revocation Policy by CAs < !" = !" !$ > !$ Total
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 42
Trends of Revocation Policy by CAs < !" = !" !$ > !$ Total
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 43
132 (2.5%) certificates are set to after expiration date Ineffective revocation All signed samples
Ineffective Revocation Date Setting 1,022 certificates, revoked out of 45,613 certificates
Wrong effective revocation date: 45 (5%) certificates 4,716 malware signed with the 45 certificates 250 (5%) signed malware is still valid
Clients remain exposed to the security threat
Outline Data collection Effectiveness of revocation process
Discovery of compromised certificates Invalidation of all signed malware Dissemination of revocation information
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 46
Enforcement in Windows Soft-fail policy for checking revocation status
Windows believes a certificate is valid unless revocation status information is available
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 47
#1. Certificates without CRLs and OCSP Points
788 certificates (0.5% out 144k): no CRLs and OCSP 86% of them were issued by Thawte before 2003 All of them already expired However, if malware is signed with the certificates and
trust-timestamped, the malware can be still valid
Clients have no means to check the status
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 48
#1. Certificates without CRLs and OCSP Points
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 49
13 CRLs (6% out of 215) are unreachable 5 CRLs: HTTP 404 Not Found error
They moved the CRLs file to another place One CRL domain is taken by a domain reseller
15 OCSP points Bad hostname, timeout, forbidden, & method not allowed
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 50
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 51
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 52
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 53
13 CRLs (6% out of 215) are unreachable 5 CRLs: HTTP 404 Not Found error
They moved the CRLs file to another place One CRL domain is taken by a domain reseller
15 OCSP points Bad hostname, timeout, forbidden, & method not allowed
Programs signed with the certificates can still be valid due to trust timestamping and soft-fail policy
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 54
#3-1. Transient Revoked Certificates in CRLs Recall: CAs, responsible for even expired certificates
But, 278 revoked certificates removed from 18 CRLs
Contacted the all CAs A CA started investigations and found the flaw And fixed the flaw thanks to our study and replied

Thank you we were removing certificates from the CRL that had expired We've modified our system to now exclude Code Signing, which means that once revoked, the certificate should remain on the CRL indefinitely.
Even CAs misunderstand the code signing PKI
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 55
#3-2. Inconsistent Responses from CRLs and OCSP
Responses from CRLs and OCSP should be consistent E.g., if one is found in CRLs, the response from OCSP for
19 certificates have inconsistent responses All certificates were issued by Go Daddy and StartField
CAs improperly maintain OCSP and CRLs servers
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 56
Conclusion The primary defense against abuse is revocation
Revocation in code signing PKI is more critical and more challenging than TLS
Hard to discover compromised certificates & samples
Erroneously setting effective revocation dates Makes malware valid although the certificate is revoked
Improper dissemination of revocation information Makes signed malware valid due to the soft-fail policy
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 57
Data Release Our data sets are available at signedmalware.org
CRLs for code signing certificates Revocation publication dates
The Broken Shield: Measuring Revocation Effectiveness in the Windows Code-Signing PKI 58
